<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_dispatch:
```c
void metal_softirq_dispatch(void)
{
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < metal_softirq_num; i++) {
		struct metal_irq *irq;
		char is_pending = 1;

		if (atomic_load(&metal_softirq_enabled[i]) != 0 &&
		    atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&metal_softirq_pending[i],
						   &is_pending, 0)) {
			irq = &metal_softirqs[i];
			(void)metal_irq_handle(irq,
					       i + metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base);
		}
	}
}
```

explanation: The MISRA C Rule 14.3 concerns controlling expressions. The other statements in the function are not controlling expressions or are clearly variant and therefore do not need investigation: - The initialization and increment expressions of the for loop (i = 0 and i++) are standard loop control operations, not separate invariant controlling expressions to be flagged. - The local initialization char is_pending = 1; is not a controlling expression; it merely provides an expected value for the atomic operation. - The assignments inside the loop (irq = &metal_softirqs[i];) and the call ( (void)metal_irq_handle(...); ) are ordinary statements with side effects and depend on the changing loop index; they are not controlling expressions. - The atomic operations invoked (atomic_load, atomic_compare_exchange_strong) are runtime actions that read/modify memory and cannot be assumed compile-time invariant; whether their results are invariant depends on the surrounding system state (not evident from this snippet) — the if-condition was included for investigation for that reason. No other controlling expressions appear in the shown code fragment.
